title_tag: Learn about Geological Microscopy for Research and Field Work
meta_description: Not all microscopes are created equally for the tasks you encounter as a geologist. The perfect microscope in the field is one that falls short of needed.

about.title: About Selenia Lusk
about.content:
I\'ve always been fascinated by rocks, and that fascination only got stronger as I grew older. I would hound my parents to take me to mineral exhibits, go to the rock and mineral conventions in Arizona and had my palaeontology phase that never really went away.
Thankfully, geology is a great paying field, so I turned my passion into a career that I enjoy every single day-whether I\'m heading out to the field on a watershed study to figure out whether construction work is contaminating the water supply or heading to a drill site to see what trace minerals and natural resources are appearing in the mudlogging study.
I work with microscopes almost every day, whether I\'m stuck in the (admittedly comfortable) research lab or under the scorching hot sun at the newest mining site. It\'s important to pick the proper tools for the task at hand, and the amount of microscopes available for geologists sent me for a spin when I first started out. Instead of letting budding geologists wander around dazed and confused, I started up this site to share my knowledge about geological microscopy. Sure, it sounds like a dull subject, but there\'s nothing cooler for me than being able to see the minerals at 1000x magnification to really understand its structure. scopy. Sure, it sounds like a dull subject, but there\'s nothing cooler for me than being able to see the minerals at 1000x magnification to really understand its structure.scopy. Sure, it sounds like a dull subject, but there\'s nothing cooler for me than being able to see the minerals at 1000x magnification to really understand its structure.

page1.slider_content: Learn about how microscopy applies to geology.
page1.title: About Microscopy
page1.content:
The basic premise of a microscope is a device that helps magnify small objects. Microscopes have been around since the 1500s in one form or another, although there are claims that microscopes may have come about even earlier than that. Back in those days, optical microscopes used light sources and mirrors to produce the magnified image.

Modern Microscopes

The modern microscopes are commonly electron microscopes, although optical microscopes are still used extensively. These moved away from using light sources in order to make an image, opting to use electrons instead. Since the electron microscope no longer used light for image production, the lenses were swapped out for electromagnets. This type of microscope first came about in 1935.

Microscopes and Technology

Many of today\'s modern marvels and technologies never would have come about without microscopes. This is especially true in the medical field, as being able to see individual cells helps immensely with researching diseases.

Microscopes and Geology

Geology also relies heavily on microscopes for identification and research purposes. Without the microscope, it would be impossible to see crystal structures that crystallography researchers need to understand how minerals are structured. Microscopes also help geologists who need to identify specific minerals, or who aren\'t entirely sure about the age of a particular rock structure or matrix. Microscopes are one of the most important tools for a geologist, so it\'s important to pick the right one, and understand all of your options before you head out into the field or the research lab. It may take some time to determine exactly what microscope matches up with your needs. One of the easiest ways to gain a greater understanding is to expose yourself to as many types of microscopes as possible, from the range of optical microscopes to electron microscopes. Each has a specific niche in the geology world, so take the time to determine whether that fancy polarising light microscope is really what you need before you take the time loading samples into it. Content Page 2 Content Page 2 Title (10-66 characters): Uses in Geology Keyword: uses in geology Page Content (300-400 words): Look around a geology field site or a research lab, and you\'re likely to see dozens of microscopes and other magnifying devices hanging around. It doesn\'t take long to realise that these are the keystone tools for the geologist trade, with many uses big and small.

Divided into Groups

Microscopes are divided into two major groups for geologists: the ones that can survive in the field, and the ones that need to make their home in the research lab. The field microscopes are the sturdier ones that are designed for analysis that you need while you\'re still out in the field. The research lab microscopes are much more powerful, but subsequently much more delicate.

Field Microscopes

Field microscopes are particularly useful when it comes to archaeology and palaeontology dig sites. These sites might not be the every day working environment for a geologist, but the situation comes up enough that there are speciality microscopes for just this purpose. Some tasks these microscopes perform include rock chip analysis, flake pattern determination, porous material analysis and contact free research.

Lab Microscopes

The primary use of microscopes within a lab environment involves identifying minerals in thin section. What this means is that a thin section of a rock or mineral sample is taken from the source piece, and placed under a microscope in order to determine all of the trace minerals and elements within this section. Typically a polarising microscope is used for this purpose, so no trace minerals are missed when examining the subject. Not only does the geologist identify what type of mineral it is using this method, they also determine things such as how long ago the mineral was formed, the circumstances of its formation and the chemical composition. Microscopes are powerful tools in the geologist\'s hands, and the amount of uses in geology is nearly countless across the various sub-disciplines, which include hydrology, oceanography and mineralogy.

page2.slider_content: Discover uses of microscopes in geology.
page2.title: Uses in Geology
page2.content:
Look around a geology field site or a research lab, and you\'re likely to see dozens of microscopes and other magnifying devices hanging around. It doesn\'t take long to realise that these are the keystone tools for the geologist trade, with many uses big and small.

Divided into Groups

Microscopes are divided into two major groups for geologists: the ones that can survive in the field, and the ones that need to make their home in the research lab. The field microscopes are the sturdier ones that are designed for analysis that you need while you\'re still out in the field. The research lab microscopes are much more powerful, but subsequently much more delicate.

Field Microscopes

Field microscopes are particularly useful when it comes to archaeology and palaeontology dig sites. These sites might not be the every day working environment for a geologist, but the situation comes up enough that there are speciality microscopes for just this purpose. Some tasks these microscopes perform include rock chip analysis, flake pattern determination, porous material analysis and contact free research.

Lab Microscopes

The primary use of microscopes within a lab environment involves identifying minerals in thin section. What this means is that a thin section of a rock or mineral sample is taken from the source piece, and placed under a microscope in order to determine all of the trace minerals and elements within this section. Typically a polarising microscope is used for this purpose, so no trace minerals are missed when examining the subject. Not only does the geologist identify what type of mineral it is using this method, they also determine things such as how long ago the mineral was formed, the circumstances of its formation and the chemical composition. Microscopes are powerful tools in the geologist\'s hands, and the amount of uses in geology is nearly countless across the various sub-disciplines, which include hydrology, oceanography and mineralogy.

page3.slider_content: Choose the microscope types for geology.
page3.title: Types of Geology Microscopes
page3.content:
You might think there\'s only a handful of microscope types that find use in geology, but you would be mistaken. Microscopes run the gamut between amateur geologist models to incredibly expensive laboratory set-ups. The right microscope is not always the most expensive one, so learning about your different options as a geologist is the perfect way to keep on track with your research.

Stereomicroscopes

Stereomicroscopes are optical microscopes that use two eyepieces. These are basic microscopes that an amateur geologist may find useful for getting a closer look at his or her specimens, but it doesn\'t give the detail that more expensive and technology driven options provide.

Compound Microscopes

Compound microscopes are the next step up. They have up to 2000x magnification, and are optical microscopes that use a single eyepiece and a light below the subject to create the magnification effect. You can see things as small as blood cells with this microscope, making it a good choice for someone starting out in looking at minerals in thin section.

Polarising Microscopes

Polarising microscopes are the ones that you find most commonly in the professional geologist\'s tool belt. This uses a special kind of light generation called polarising light, which creates images that you do not see with normal light sources. These types of microscopes are the industry standard across the board, as they provide the most insight and detail into the mineral structure and chemical composition.

Metallurgical Microscopes

Metallurgical microscopes are used specifically for examining metal, which is a common situation in the geology world. These are not particularly powerful microscopes, but they have features that make it easier to look at metals for defects, inclusions and other small details.

Field Microscopes

Finally, the field microscope is a compact, hand held option that makes it simple for a geologist to do quick research and examination in the middle of a field situation. They are also designed to be quite durable to keep up with the needs of the field. Whether you\'re a veteran or amateur, make sure you get the right microscope for the job you need.

homepage.content:
[widgetkit id=ab_slider_id]

Geological Microscopy

Microscopy in Geology

When you think about geology, you probably think about giant oil rigs or people digging for rocks. You might not immediately think of the geologist going back to the lab and whipping out the microscope to determine what they found when they are out in the field. Microscopes are found in many aspects of geology, especially as this field combines studies from other hard sciences as well, such as chemistry and biology, which also rely on heavy microscope usage and other devices. age and other devices.

Microscope Use in Geology

It\'s harder to find a part of geology that doesn\'t use microscopes than one that does. Microscopes are invaluable in many areas of this subject, especially when it comes to mineralogy and crystallography. Microscopes help with identifying minerals, discovering the types of inclusions that are in oil, and helping research the environments that the geologist works in. Geology is a multi-disciplinary area, so the geologist often needs to use the microscope for research that involves chemistry and other subject areas.

Microscope Types

One of the most exciting facets of geology is that the field has a wide range of jobs and research available. This also means that the fancy electron microscope that\'s in the lab is not the one the geologist is going to lug out to the middle of the Arctic Circle to look at the structure of the ice there. Understanding the types of microscopes helps you to understand exactly which ones would be best used in a particular area of geology, whether you\'re limited by the environment or budget. or budget.

privacy.title: Content & Privacy Policy
privacy.content: Privacy Policy of GEOLOGICALMICROSCOPY.COM Types of Data collected Other Personal Data collected may be described in other sections of this privacy policy or by dedicated explanation text contextually with the Data collection. The Personal Data may be freely provided by the User, or collected automatically when using this Application. Any use of Cookies - or of other tracking tools - by this Application or by the owners of third party services used by this Application, unless stated otherwise, serves to identify Users and remember their preferences, for the sole purpose of providing the service required by the User. Failure to provide certain Personal Data may make it impossible for this Application to provide its services. The User assumes responsibility for the Personal Data of third parties published or shared through this Application and declares to have the right to communicate or broadcast them, thus relieving the Data Controller of all responsibility. Mode and place of processing the Data Method of processing The Data Controller processes the Data of Users in proper manner and shall take appropriate security measures to prevent unauthorized access, disclosure, modification or unauthorized destruction of the Data. Access to the Data may be available to Data Processors, if appointed, as well as employees involved with the processing. Access to Data may be also available to external parties providing services to the Data Controller such as third party technical service providers, mail carriers, hosting providers, IT companies, communication agencies. The updated list of these parties may be requested from the Data Controller at any time. Place The Data is processed at the Data Controller headquarters, unless stated otherwise in the rest of this document. Conservation Time The Data is kept for the time necessary to provide the service requested by the User, or stated by the purposes outlined in this document, and the User can always request the Data Controller for their suspension or removal. Additional information about Data collection and processing Legal Action The User's Personal Data may be used for legal purposes by the Data Controller, in Court or in the stages leading to possible legal action arising from improper use of this Application or the related services. Additional Information about User's Personal Data In addition to the information in this privacy policy, this Application may provide the User with contextual information concerning particular services or the collection and processing of Personal Data. System Logs and Maintenance For operation and maintenance purposes, this Application and any third party services may collect files that record interaction with this Application (System Logs) or use for this purpose other Personal Data (such as IP Address). Information not contained in this policy More details concerning the collection or processing of Personal Data may be requested from the Data Controller at any time at its contact information. The rights of Users Users have the right, at any time, to know whether their Personal Data has been stored and can consult the Data Controller to learn about their contents and origin, to verify their accuracy or to ask for them to be supplemented, cancelled, updated or corrected, or for their transformation into anonymous format or to block any data held in violation of the law, as well as to oppose their treatment for any and all legitimate reasons. Requests should be sent to the Data Controller at the contact information set out above. This Application does not support “do not track” requests. To understand if any of the third party services it uses honor the “do not track” requests, please read their privacy policies. Changes to this privacy policy The Data Controller reserves the right to make changes to this privacy policy at any time by giving notice to its Users on this page. It is strongly recommended to check this page often, referring to the date of the last modification listed at the bottom. If a User objects to any of the changes to the Policy, the User must cease using this Application and can request the Data Controller to erase the Personal Data. Unless stated otherwise, the then-current privacy policy applies to all Personal Data the Data Controller has about Users.
